pros: Great group of people to work with. I am accepted and making a valuable contribution to the college.
cons: There is no depth in the staff. There is no back up for sick employees, or if an employee leaves.
The pay isn’t worth the amount of work put in.

pros: Was pretty hands off with nice people and a good opportunity to learn and grow after
cons: In transition and may not be sustainable as a business. Don’t love the new leadership; too much of a despot without know-how and reason.

pros: The kids were great and eager to learn, for the most part.
cons: Adjunct work very hard for very little. No chance at full-time employment unless you're a Ph.D.

job_title: Assistant Director of Career Services in Waterville, ME
pros: The students are great! The campus is very nice with a strong community feel.
cons: Staff raises are few, if any, and do not keep pace with cost of living or inflation.

pros: Great leadership and direction for future
cons: Small environment lends itself to need to wear many hats

pros: Nice workplace and freedom to work on own pace
cons: A lot of tasks to do at once

job_title: Associate Director of Operations in Waterville, ME
pros: Family culture, small and friendly community based school that cares deeply for the students.
cons: The school size is roughly about 1,000 people, so those looking for a larger environment could think this is a con.

pros: Calm, professional, and friendly environment. Culture of greetings and holding the door for the next person. The students are usually open to learning and understand how their education will impact their future. Many students are juggling part and full-time jobs while going to school and a high percentage are first generation. They tend to have ambition and a strong work ethic. Benefits are pretty good and better than some comparable colleges. Administration often grants employee appreciation days around holidays, to help employees be with their families. As an employee, your children can go to college tuition-free (to Thomas or other partner schools).
cons: Because Thomas often hires and promotes from the inside, this may contribute to its a lack of diversity. Pay is lower than you might expect and there are limited opportunities for advancement. Departments are siloed and there is very little interaction between them. There is not a "community feel" among employees beyond their departments and those they work with closely. This can lead members of smaller departments and new employees feeling isolated.

review_title: Faculty care about the students; marketing and PR people overhype the college
pros:
Faculty have real-world experience and care about helping students
Small campus has its benefits; people are friendly.
cons:
Marketing is dishonest "Thomas College is a leading liberal arts college..." It's neither leading, nor a liberal arts college.
Salaries are poverty level. They claim they survey other colleges, but they must look at other D-rated schools.

pros: This is a great college who is organized, friendly, and is always improving to offer the best services to their students
cons: The cons are very minimum as it relates to this school. The only real con is that it is a big investment but it pays off in the end

pros:
Friendly environment - co-workers are great.
Positive attitude
management is friendly
cons:
Pay is low
Management sometimes too friendly, and can't push authority
